summary: The document is a memorandum from a June 5, 1964, meeting of the Covert Action Panel under the President's Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board (PFIAB), detailing discussions on covert operations and intelligence activities in various countries including Cuba, Chile, Brazil, Southeast Asia (South Vietnam and Laos), the Congo, and Cyprus. Key participants included Mr. Peter Jessup, Secretary of the Special NSC 5412/2 Group, and CIA officials Dick Helms and Cord Meyer. Topics included the approval process for covert actions, cessation of sabotage operations in Cuba, political support in Chile, challenges in Southeast Asia, and the Congo crisis. The document also notes the absence of a systematic review for past covert actions and emphasizes the need for monitoring within the Special Group.
key_findings: The Special Group, led by Mr. McGeorge Bundy, convenes weekly to deliberate on covert actions, mainly proposed by the CIA.
In 1964, covert operations spanned Cuba, Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos, Panama, Chile, Congo, Angola, Tibet, Zanzibar, and China.
The CIA provided financial support to the Christian Democrat candidate Frei in Chile, among other anti-Communist initiatives.
Concerns in Southeast Asia focused on South Vietnam's political instability and difficulties in intelligence operations in North Vietnam.
The document underscores the lack of a structured review mechanism for evaluating the results of past covert actions.
Discussions also addressed the Cyprus crisis and the possibility of Turkish military involvement.
